messages.content: I am planning a trip from Hyderabad, India, to Delhi, India. I need to book flight tickets. Find me the most economical direct flight. How long does it take to travel from Hyderabad to Delhi via flight? Additionally, could you suggest some budget-friendly hotels in Delhi for my stay?

reasoning: To find the most economical direct flights from Hyderabad to Delhi, I will use the flight search tool with the specific details of the origin and destination along with today's date.

messages.name: amadeus_travel
messages.content:
{
  "status": "error",
  "message": "Amadeus API not available: AMADEUS_CLIENT_ID is missing, AMADEUS_CLIENT_SECRET is missing. Please configure valid AMADEUS_CLIENT_ID and AMADEUS_CLIENT_SECRET environment variables.",
  "error_type": "api_key_error",
  "client_id_set": false,
  "client_secret_set": false,
  "help": "To get valid Amadeus API credentials, visit: https://developers.amadeus.com/register"
}

reasoning: The Amadeus API is unavailable due to missing credentials. I will try finding direct flights from Hyderabad to Delhi using the Google Flights API instead.

reasoning: I have obtained flight information for direct flights from Hyderabad to Delhi, including their durations. Now, I will search for budget-friendly hotels in Delhi for your stay.

messages.name: google_hotels

reasoning: I have successfully gathered flight information for a direct flight from Hyderabad to Delhi, including the duration of the flight. Now I will provide the user with a summary of this flight along with recommendations for budget-friendly hotels for their stay in Delhi.

messages.content:
The most economical direct flight from Hyderabad to Delhi is operated by Air India (Flight AI 2880). It departs from Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (HYD) at 18:10 and arrives at Indira Gandhi International Airport (DEL) at 20:45. The total duration is 155 minutes, and the ticket price is $85.

Here are some budget-friendly hotels in Delhi for your stay from October 11, 2025:
1. **Hotel Viva Palace** - Rating: 4.1 from 4,537 reviews, Price: $25 per night.
   ![Hotel Viva Palace](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/p/AF1QipN8y0hDkSRRjCJY6TvfVlD97co0xGE6iO70uBs=s287-w287-h192-n-k-no-v1)

2. **Staybook Atlanta New Delhi Train Station** - Rating: 4.4 from 2,014 reviews, Price: $16 per night.
   ![Staybook Atlanta](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/proxy/BE4C_RhnHT-IsZ0ootX0jMBe6p3mFtt0tHWX2RZZJwtRQhlN3e9ZgYY4oMb5kxnjmDRsh2jBe8_8lwGWQvIRSw1v_CLzKaieG-dGVzSpzQVhG34GumAWyqaWyUCsxKDhBrFkCK45Lh83aJPrm8Sq7UOJ1bkdIA=s287-w287-h192-n-k-no-v1)

3. **Hotel Vijaydeep Place Near Delhi Airport** - Rating: 4.7 from 414 reviews, Price: $10 per night.
   ![Hotel Vijaydeep](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/p/AF1QipMr0e4qYRL3FjOfPbFuDT66wJJ4ItoIl1M3IVQf=s287-w287-h192-n-k-no-v1)

4. **Hotel Prince Palace Deluxe** - Rating: 4.1 from 152 reviews, Price: $9 per night.
   ![Hotel Prince Palace](https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/proxy/TG_dt54Sd-7J00h3eEgd8gZBrqDoY24IB5k9kIgSLP96pjHqFdhvxqxunWeCRH1NhjTa_Z0TDVi_szN9qQIbEVxo7ouHmiMkqq5nNTHC9serHuyaiZVDyAUSGgit-jCAx43gLFZgfI0S0oio7OmXfOdkdVRmPjI=s287-w287-h192-n-k-no-v1)

Please let me know if you need any more information or assistance with bookings!
I am looking for sightseeing places in Delhi. Also, tell me which is the oldest monument in Delhi, and explain to me the history of this monument.

reasoning: To find sightseeing places and the oldest monument in Delhi along with its history, I'll perform a web search with relevant keywords to gather comprehensive information.

Spanning over 2,000 years, the city offers a treasure trove of history, architecture, and culture including ancient forts, tombs, and grand ...\"}, {\"title\": \"Top 10 Historical Places in Delhi You Can't-Miss - Luxotic Travel Blog\", \"link\": \"https://luxoticholidays.com/blog/top-10-historical-places-in-delhi/\", \"snippet\": \"Historical Places in Delhi has a rich history and this is manifested in its numerous historical monuments like The Jama Masjid, The Lal Qila, Purana Quila and Hauz Khas.\"}, {\"title\": \"Historical Places Near Delhi : Most Famous Historical Places in Delhi | MakeMyTrip\", \"link\": \"https://www.makemytrip.com/tripideas/heritage-delhi\", \"snippet\": \"With its flavourful street food, flea markets, monuments from different eras, throbbing nightlife, sprawling parks, posh colonies, old quarters, exclusive clubs and places of worship\\u2013 the colouful metropolis of Delhi is a glorious blend of diverse cultures, languages and faiths\"}, {\"title\": \"80 Places to visit around Delhi to gain some unforgettable experience\", \"link\": \"https://www.incredibleindia.gov.in/en/delhi/delhi/80-places-to-visit-near-delhi\", \"snippet\": \"The best time to visit this place ... km from Delhi is between October and March. Now, I need to summarize the historical significance of the Qutub Minar for the user. I will use Wikipedia to provide the detailed history of Qutub Minar.

messages.name: wikipedia
messages.content:
Page: Qutb Minar
Summary: The Qutb Minar, also spelled Qutub Minar and Qutab Minar, is a minaret and victory tower comprising the Qutb complex, which lies at the site of Delhi's oldest fortified city, Lal Kot, founded by the Tomar Rajputs. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site in the Mehrauli area of South Delhi, India. It was mostly built between 1199 and 1220, contains 399 steps, and is one of the most-frequented heritage spots in the city. After defeating Prithviraj Chauhan, the last Hindu ruler of Delhi before the Ghurid conquest of the region, Qutab-ud-din Aibak initiated the construction of the victory tower, but only managed to finish the first level. It was to mark the beginning of Islamic rule in the region. Successive dynasties of the Delhi Sultanate continued the construction, and, in 1368, Firuz Shah Tughlaq rebuilt the top parts and added a cupola.
It can be compared to the 62-metre all-brick Minaret of Jam in Afghanistan, of c. 1190, which was constructed a decade or so before the probable start of the Delhi tower. The surfaces of both are elaborately decorated with inscriptions and geometric patterns. The Qutb Minar has a shaft that is fluted with "superb stalactite bracketing under the balconies" at the top of each stage. In general, minarets were slow to be used in India and are often detached from the main mosque where they exist.
In recent years, the Qutub Minar has been illuminated for special occasions involving international relations. In September 2023, the monument was lit up in the colours of the Mexican flag to commemorate Mexico's 213th Independence Day, an event that was acknowledged and appreciated by the Embassy of Mexico in India. Similarly, on October 30, the Qutub Minar was illuminated with the Turkish flag to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Republic of Turkey, an occasion that received special attention from the Turkish Embassy in New Delhi.

Page: Qutb Minar complex
Summary: The Qutb Minar complex are monuments and buildings from the Delhi Sultanate at Mehrauli in Delhi, India. Construction of the Qutub Minar "victory tower" in the complex, named after the religious figure Sufi Saint Khwaja Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, was begun by Qutb-ud-din Aibak, who later became the first Sultan of Delhi of the Mamluk dynasty (Gulam Vansh). It was continued by his successor Iltutmish (a.k.a. Altamash), and finally completed much later by Firoz Shah Tughlaq, a Sultan of Delhi from the Tughlaq dynasty (1320–1412) in 1368 AD. The Qubbat-ul-Islam Mosque (Dome of Islam), later corrupted into Quwwat-ul Islam, stands next to the Qutb Minar.
Many subsequent rulers, including the Tughlaqs, Alauddin Khalji and the British added structures to the complex. Apart from the Qutb Minar and the Quwwat ul-Islam Mosque, other structures in the complex include the Alai Darwaza gate, the Alai Minar and the Iron pillar.
Inside the complex lie the tombs of Iltutmish, Alauddin Khalji and Imam Zamin.
Today, the adjoining area spread over with a host of old monuments, including Balban's tomb, has been developed by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) as the Mehrauli Archaeological Park, and INTACH has restored some 40 monuments in the Park. It is also the venue of the annual 'Qutub Festival', held in November–December, where artists, musicians and dancers perform over three days.

Page: Mini Qutub Minar
Summary: The Mini Qutub Minar (local: Chhota Qutub Minar, Mini Minar, Kaushal Minar, Hastsal ki Laat) is a minaret tower in Hastsal village, near Uttam Nagar in West Delhi, Delhi, India. It was built in the 1650 by the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan (reign, 1628-1658) near his hunting lodge in Hasthal.  The three-storey tower is 16.87 meters (55 feet) tall and stands on a raised octagonal platform. The minar (minaret) is built with bricks and clad with red sandstone. The tower structure and design resembles the Qutub Minar of Delhi and was inspired by it.
Originally, the Mini Qutub Minar was a 5-storey tower, topped out with a do

messages.content: Some great sightseeing places in Delhi are Mughal architectural marvels like the Red Fort and Humayun's Tomb, iconic landmarks such as India Gate and the Qutub Minar, and religious sites like the Lotus Temple, Akshardham Temple, and Gurudwara Bangla Sahib. Visitors can also explore government buildings like Rashtrapati Bhavan, astronomical observatories at Jantar Mantar, and bustling markets like Chandni Chowk. Here is some detailed information about the Qutub Minar. The Qutub Minar is a minaret and victory tower located in the Mehrauli area of Delhi, India. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and was built mostly between 1199 and 1220 AD. The tower was commissioned by Qutub-ud-din Aibak to mark the beginning of Islamic rule in India after his victory over the last Hindu ruler, Prithviraj Chauhan. Originally, Aibak only completed the first level, while successive rulers continued the construction, and it was completed by Firuz Shah Tughlaq in 1368. The tower stands at 72.5 meters tall, decorated with intricate carvings and verses from the Quran. The Qutub Minar is recognized as one of the most frequented heritage sites in the region alongside the Qutub complex, which includes several other historic structures. Its architectural significance lies in its elaborate decoration, fine craftsmanship, and as a symbol of Delhi's historical transition.
